description: Uncertain. Perhaps from Middle English scope (“scoop”) or Dutch schop (“shovel”)  +‎ -er; or from Dutch scheppen (“to draw off”).

entries.meaning: (nautical) A drainage hole on the deck of a ship.
(architecture) A similar opening in a wall or parapet that allows water to drain from a roof.

description: Of unknown origin; possibly verbized form of Etymology 1, but this is unlikely.

verbs.description: scupper (third-person singular simple present scuppers, present participle scuppering, simple past and past participle scuppered)

entries.meaning: (Britain) Thwart or destroy, especially something belonging or pertaining to another.
examples: The bad media coverage scuppered his chances of being elected.
